title: Waxy (horse)
text:
Waxy (1790 – 18 April 1818) was a British <a href="Thoroughbred">Thoroughbred</a> racehorse that won the 1793 <a href="Epsom%20Derby">Epsom Derby</a> and was an influential sire in the late eighteenth and early part of the nineteenth century. Waxy was bred by Sir Ferdinando Poole and was foaled at <a href="Lewes">Lewes</a> in 1790. He was sired by <a href="Pot-8-Os">Pot-8-Os</a>, a son of the foundation stallion <a href="Eclipse%20%28horse%29">Eclipse</a>, whose genetic lineage traced to the <a href="Darley%20Arabian">Darley Arabian</a>. Waxy's <a href="Mare">dam</a>, Maria, was sired by the influential stallion <a href="Herod%20%28horse%29">Herod</a> and produced one full-brother to Waxy, who was named Worthy. Waxy derived his name from a variety of potato, a choice that was inspired by his sire's name. Trained by <a href="Robert%20Robson">Robert Robson</a>, Waxy won nine races out of 15 starts during his four-year racing career, retiring from racing at the age of seven in 1797 after sustaining an injury during his last start.
Beginning in 1798, Waxy stood at <a href="Stud%20farm">stud</a> at Sir Poole's estate in Lewes and remained there until Poole's death in 1804. After Poole's death, Waxy was acquired by the <a href="Augustus%20FitzRoy%2C%203rd%20Duke%20of%20Grafton">3rd Duke of Grafton</a> and stood at his <a href="Euston%20Hall">Euston Hall</a> stud. Waxy remained at Euston Hall for the remainder of his life and was used as a breeding stallion until his death on 18 April 1818. His most notable offspring were produced under the ownership of the 3rd Duke of Grafton and his son. Waxy produced 190 winners of races during his stud career, siring four <a href="Epsom%20Derby">Epsom Derby</a> and three <a href="Epsom%20Oaks">Epsom Oaks</a> winners, becoming a <a href="Leading%20sire%20in%20Great%20Britain%20and%20Ireland">leading sire</a> in 1810. His most notable sons that achieved success in the stud were <a href="Whalebone%20%28horse%29">Whalebone</a> and <a href="Whisker%20%28horse%29">Whisker</a>. Through the produce of these two sons, Waxy became the paternal ancestor of most of the world's male Thoroughbreds by the mid-twentieth century.
Background.
Waxy was bred by Sir Ferdinando Poole, a <a href="baronet">baronet</a> whose family seat was in <a href="Poole%2C%20Cheshire">Poole, Cheshire</a>. Sir Ferdinando leased an extensive estate in <a href="Lewes">Lewes</a> that was built on land once owned by the <a href="Grey%20Friars">Grey Friars</a> and was called "The Friary." Waxy was foaled in 1790 at Poole's stable at The Friary.
The colt was named "Waxy" to distinguish him from Poole's other colt sired by <a href="Potoooooooo">Pot-8-Os</a> out of the mare Macaria, which was subsequently named "Mealy." Waxy and mealy were two types of potatoes available at the time and are a play on the name of the colts' sire Pot-8-Os, which is itself a pun on the name "Potatoes." A variant spelling, "Waxey," is mentioned in some publications.
Ancestry.
Waxy's sire, Pot-8-Os, was a successful sire of racehorses that had won 34 races during his seven-year racing career. In addition to Waxy, Pot-8-Os produced the mare <a href="Parasol%20%28horse%29">Parasol</a> (the dam of Partisan) and the colt Lottery. Waxy was Pot-8-Os most successful son in the breeding shed, with Waxy's sons carrying on the direct-male line well into the 20th century.
Waxy's <a href="mare">dam</a>, Maria, was bred by <a href="Frederick%20St%20John%2C%202nd%20Viscount%20Bolingbroke">Lord Bolingbroke</a> and was sired by the Thoroughbred foundation sire <a href="Herod%20%28horse%29">Herod</a>. She produced ten foals between 1784 and 1797, with Waxy being her sixth foal and one of two by Pot-8-Os. Waxy's full-brother, Worthy (foaled in 1795), was a moderately successful racer and was later a breeding stallion for the <a href="East%20India%20Company">East India Company</a>. Maria died in 1797, about two weeks after foaling the <a href="filly">filly</a> Wowski, later the dam of Derby winner <a href="Smolensko%20%28horse%29">Smolensko</a>, Sir Charles and Thunderbolt.
Description.
In the words of jockey <a href="Sam%20Chifney%2C%20Jr.">Sam Chifney</a>, Waxy was a "handsome, rich <a href="bay%20%28color%29">bay</a>, with a white stocking on the off-hind [right] leg, good length, and especially beautiful quarters." In the words of his exercise rider (who wrote an anonymous letter to "<a href="The%20Sporting%20Magazine">The Sporting Magazine</a>" in 1828), Waxy was "one of the finest formed horses, perfect in symmetry, beautiful in colour, admirable in all his paces, and of the finest temper when in work." However, when Waxy was confined to a stall during the winter months, his temperament became unruly and unpredictable leading the anonymous writer to remark that, "Oft has he kicked the lappets of my coat over my head." One of the few, possibly only, surviving portraits of Waxy was painted by <a href="Francis%20Sartorius">Francis Sartorius</a> in 1794 or 1795, and the depiction was praised in commentary for "Sporting Magazine" for its "neatness" and for "the truth of representation it so evidently display[ed]." While most breeding stallions and racehorses of the era had stable companions, Waxy reportedly was fond of rabbits in his later years and "was never happy without a rabbit in his paddock" with one female rabbit making her nest in the middle of his stall and raising generations of rabbits at the site that were never harmed by Waxy.
Racing career.
Waxy did not race at the age of two years, and his first turf appearance was at the spring meeting at <a href="Newmarket%2C%20Suffolk">Newmarket</a>. Waxy was trained by <a href="Robert%20Robson">Robert Robson</a>, who worked for Sir Ferdinando Poole in <a href="Lewes">Lewes</a> for several years from about 1792. Waxy's main and most celebrated racing rival was <a href="George%20Wyndham%2C%203rd%20Earl%20of%20Egremont">Lord Egremont</a>'s colt <a href="Gohanna%20%28horse%29">Gohanna</a> (first described as "Brother to Precipitate") who was called the "Pride of <a href="Petworth%20House">Petworth</a>." Waxy raced Gohanna five times in his career, beating him in all but one race, a <a href="match%20race">match race</a> at Newmarket in 1794 where Waxy carried two more pounds than Gohanna and lost by half a head. Waxy was perceived as an excellent racehorse during his racing career. So much so that in one alleged incident, Waxy was mistakenly seized as a <a href="heriot">heriot</a> after the proprietor of a <a href="Godstone">Godstone</a> inn where he was staying suddenly died. Being the finest horse in the stable, and assuming he was owned by the stablemaster he was briefly taken by the landowner. Waxy raced until he was seven years old and retired from racing after he was injured in his last start. He was then used as a breeding stallion by Poole at Lewes.
1793: three-year-old season.
The <a href="Epsom%20Derby">Epsom Derby</a> occurred on 18 May and was attended by "as numerous a company as ever appeared on the course." Eleven horses lined up for the start, seven of them sired by Pot-8-Os. The starting odds for Waxy to win the Derby were 100 to 7 and 100 to 10 (depending on the <a href="bookmaker">bookmaking</a> operation) and at the <a href="Tattersalls">Tattersalls</a> betting room he "was so little thought of, that he had never been mentioned" in the betting. The race favorite was <a href="George%20Wyndham%2C%203rd%20Earl%20of%20Egremont">Lord Egremont</a>'s colt "Brother to Precipitate" (later named <a href="Gohanna">Gohanna</a> in 1795) with this horse taking the lead in the initial strides of the race. Waxy pushed Brother to Precipitate (a "bump" in modern racing terms) at the track's first turn, taking and maintaining the lead to become an "easy winner" of the Derby. Three of the top four finishers were sired by Pot-8-Os, with second-place finisher Brother to Precipitate being the exception. The meeting was also notable for a "dreadful accident," a collision between a servant on horseback with the colt Exiseman, the winner of the race after the Derby, and for the antics of <a href="John%20Lade">John Lade</a> dressed in a "loose undress of blue and white striped <a href="Trousers">trowsers</a>" asking the crowd to determine whether he was "the captain of a <a href="privateer">privateer</a> or an <a href="ambassador">ambassador</a> from the <a href="Mughal%20Empire">Great Mogul</a>."
At <a href="Lewes">Lewes</a> on 1 August, Waxy won an 80-guinea sweepstakes race against Lord Egremont's colt Mercury while carrying seven pounds more than the other horses in the race as a handicap for his win in the Derby. At <a href="Abingdon%2C%20Oxfordshire">Abingdon</a> on 11 September, Waxy won a two-mile 40-<a href="Guinea%20%28British%20coin%29">guinea</a> sweepstakes race against the colt Rockingham.
1794: four-year-old season.
Waxy won the Jockey Club Plate at the Second Spring meeting at <a href="Newmarket%20Racecourse">Newmarket</a> in May. At the same meeting a few days later, Waxy was beaten by <a href="George%20Wyndham%2C%203rd%20Earl%20of%20Egremont">Lord Egremont</a>'s colt Brother to Precipitate in a <a href="match%20race">match race</a>. On At <a href="Ipswich">Ipswich</a> on 1 July, Waxy won a match race against <a href="Sir%20Charles%20Bunbury%2C%206th%20Baronet">Charles Bunbury</a>'s colt Robin Gray. At Lewes in July, Waxy ran against his previous rival, Brother to Precipitate, and won both heats in the four-mile Duke of Richmond's Plate for horses bred in <a href="Suffolk">Suffolk</a>. On the same day, Waxy was the only horse that presented for the 60-guinea Ladies' Plate and won by default (termed as a "<a href="walkover">walk over</a>").
1795: five-year-old season.
At <a href="Oxford">Oxford</a> on 18 August, Waxy was second in a 100-guinea cup race to Mr. Durand's <a href="filly">filly</a> Hermione. At Lewes on 6 August, Waxy was third in the four-mile Ladies' Plate to the colt Guildford and <a href="George%20Wyndham%2C%203rd%20Earl%20of%20Egremont">Lord Egremont</a>'s horse Gohanna. On 19 September at <a href="Salisbury">Salisbury</a>, Waxy won two heats to win the 100-guinea His Majesty's Plate against the five-year-old horse Guatimozin.
1796: six-year-old season.
At the First Spring meeting, Waxy was second in the 100-guinea King's Plate to the colt Gabriel. In March at <a href="Newmarket%2C%20Suffolk">Newmarket</a>, Waxy was third in the first class of the Oatland Stakes to the colts Viret and Pecker. In May, Waxy won His Majesty's Plate at <a href="Guildford">Guildford</a> against Gohanna and Guildford. On 31 August at Salisbury, Waxy won two four-mile heats against Gohanna for the 100-guinea His Majesty's Plate.
1797: seven-year-old season.
On 18 July at <a href="Oxford">Oxford</a> in the running for the Gold Cup, Waxy did not place and was noted to have "broke down" during the running. This was his last appearance on the turf and he was retired to <a href="stud%20farm">stud</a> the following season in 1798.
Stud career.
Waxy first stood at Lewes for a fee of 10 guineas per mare and a groom fee of 10 <a href="shilling">shilling</a>s. In September 1803, Sir Ferdinando Poole offered to sell Waxy for 700 guineas to William Lightfoot, an agent sent to buy horses for Virginian turfman <a href="John%20Tayloe%20III">John Tayloe</a>. Lightfoot refused to buy Waxy, writing to Tayloe, "he has lost an eye, and is thirteen years old, and I think his health bad." Instead Lightfoot purchased Waxy's half-sister Keren Happuch who was <a href="Horse%20breeding%23Live%20cover">covered</a> by Waxy that year. It is unclear how Waxy lost his eye, its loss occurring sometime between 1797 and 1803. Sir Ferdinando Poole died on 8 June 1804, and Waxy was then acquired by the <a href="Augustus%20FitzRoy%2C%203rd%20Duke%20of%20Grafton">Duke of Grafton</a> and relocated to the <a href="Euston%20Hall">Euston Hall</a> stud near Newmarket. Under the Duke's ownership, his fee increased to 25 guineas per mare and he covered 40 mares per season.
Waxy died on 18 April 1818 at the advanced age (for a Thoroughbred) of 28, having gone completely blind a few years before his death. He was buried at Newmarket, close to All Saints Church.
Legacy.
Waxy produced 190 winners in his stud career, including four winners of the Epsom Derby and three winners of <a href="Epsom%20Oaks">The Oaks</a>. His first Derby winner, <a href="Pope%20%28horse%29">Waxy Pope</a>, was foaled when Waxy was 16 years old and most of his notable offspring were produced in the last nine years of his life under the ownership of the <a href="Augustus%20FitzRoy%2C%203rd%20Duke%20of%20Grafton">Duke of Grafton</a> and his son. Waxy was the leading sire in 1810, mostly due to the racing success of Pope and Whalebone. His importance to Thoroughbred genetics and prevalence in the "<a href="General%20Stud%20Book">General Stud Book</a>" led him to be likened to "the ace of trumps," the most powerful card in <a href="contract%20bridge">bridge</a>, due in part to the success of his sons <a href="Whisker%20%28horse%29">Whisker</a> and <a href="Whalebone%20%28horse%29">Whalebone</a>. In the mid-20th century, the <a href="paternal">paternal</a> line of most of the world's male Thoroughbreds traced to the <a href="Darley%20Arabian">Darley Arabian</a> through Waxy, and Waxy's line was one of only three male lines tracing to <a href="Eclipse%20%28horse%29">Eclipse</a> that persisted into the 20th century (the others tracing through <a href="Hambletonian%20%28horse%29">Hambletonian</a> and Joe Andrews). In the words of 20th-century Thoroughbred pedigree analyst John Furman Wall, "with his advent, superb quality was a reality."
Notable offspring.
Waxy produced four <a href="Epsom%20Derby">Epsom Derby</a> winners: Waxy Pope (1809), <a href="Whalebone%20%28horse%29">Whalebone</a> (1810), <a href="Blucher%20%28horse%29">Blucher</a> (1814) and <a href="Whisker%20%28horse%29">Whisker</a> (1815). He also sired three <a href="filly">fillies</a> that won <a href="Epsom%20Oaks">The Oaks</a>: Music (1813), Minuet (1815) and Corinne (1818). Corinne also won the <a href="1%2C000%20Guineas%20Stakes">1,000 Guineas Stakes</a> in 1818. His most productive offspring were produced by the mare <a href="Penelope%20%28horse%29">Penelope</a> (by Trumpator) and include Whalebone, Whisker, Web, Woful, Wire and Wilful. Penelope was bred and owned by the Duke of Grafton, and all of her foals were foaled at Euston Hall. Whisker was more notable for siring <a href="mare">broodmares</a>, and Whalebone was a good producer of <a href="colt%20%28horse%29">colts</a>. Waxy Pope was a leading sire in Ireland and Blucher was a marginally successful sire.
